what: A package for Blanco Center staff
title: blancocentR
text: package includes resources help achieve cohesive look Blanco Center data visualizations. main use blancocentR conjunction ggplot2, colors can used across tools, included data can useful applications don’t involve data visualizations. Version 1.0.0 updates (Fall 2025): ggplot themes theme_bc() got major update, including new features released ggplot2 4.0.0. longer relies {sysfonts} {showtext}1 original theme_bc() now available theme_bc_legacy() added theme_lafirst()2 new: gt theme added gt_theme_bc() style gt tables3 colors added LA FIRST colors data included long-format versions louisiana parishes

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff
title: blancocentR
text: BlancocentR includes two datasets available objects help working Louisiana’s 64 parishes region designations different state agencies organizations: tibble parishes includes parishes regions, louisiana sf object includes population estimates, geometry, center points parish addition included parishes. now available long-format well (parishes_long louisiana_long). can access data via blancocentR::parishes blancocentR::louisiana, can load environment. Let’s load ! can now plot simple map Louisiana outlines parish.  can use ‘fill’ aesthetic designate different regions, e.g., DCFS regions.
code: data(parishes) data(louisiana) library(ggplot2)  p1 <- ggplot(louisiana) + geom_sf() p1 p2 <- ggplot(louisiana) + geom_sf(aes(fill = region_name_DCFS), show.legend = FALSE)   p2 + labs(title = "Louisiana regions designated by DCFS")

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff > The data
title: blancocentR
text: 1.0.0 update, include long-format versions data: parishes_long louisiana_long. region names now stored variable region_name region numbers region_number. Organizations/agencies variable org. can filter agency want call regions like next example.
code: library(blancocentR) library(glue) library(dplyr) data(louisiana_long) org_var <- "LDH"  louisiana_long %>%    filter(org == org_var) %>%    ggplot() +   geom_sf(aes(fill = region_name)) +   labs(title = glue("Louisiana regions designated by {org_var}"))

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff
title: blancocentR
text: Sometimes ’s useful parish polygons also region polygons. Maybe ’d like map Louisiana’s parishes show region boundaries without using ‘fill’ regions. Maybe ’d like plop region’s name center area. can using get_region_geometry(). Let’s use DCFS regions example! sf object changed 64 observations (one parish) 9 observations (one DCFS region). Let’s plot map!
code: dcfs_regions <- get_region_geometry(louisiana, region_DCFS, region_name_DCFS) ggplot(dcfs_regions) +    geom_sf(data = louisiana) + # parish boundaries   geom_sf(lwd = 0.7, fill = NA) + # region boundaries   geom_sf_text(aes(label = region_name_DCFS)) # region names

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff
title: blancocentR
text: package includes Blanco Center theme, theme_bc(), theme_bc_legacy(), theme_lafirst() ggplot styling, gt_theme_bc() gt table styling.

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff > The themes
title: blancocentR
text: Please note theme_bc() now requires ggplot2 ver. 4.0.0 higher, ships functionality released ggplot2 update (e.g., arguments ink, paper, accent). original version theme_bc() now available new name: theme_bc_legacy() reluctant update ggplot2. arguments base_font title_font renamed base_family header_family, respectively, line ggplot2 argument names. BlancocentR includes Blanco Center theme, theme_bc(). theme defines use font families, sizes, colors different aspects plot structure. base text defined using sans serif font (“Quicksand”) size 12 color light_text (“#575E66”). plot structure (e.g., axis lines, ticks, text) use color light_text well, titles (plot title, legend title, axis titles) emphasizes using serif font “Bitter” color dark_text (“#1A242F”). extra emphasis ULL color branding, plot title uses ull_red (“#a00b0b”). New arguments came ggplot2 4.0.0 update include 1) ink, foreground color default light_text, 2) paper, background color, “white” default, 3) accent, accent color col_la (“#4776aa”) default. default position legend defined theme top plot horizontal direction can changed needed. can customize theme changing arguments. Let’s create additional example plots use throughout tutorial.  Let’s see plot p3 looks add theme:
code: library(scales)  p3 <- ggplot(trees, aes(x = Girth, y = Height)) +   geom_point(aes(size = Volume)) +   geom_smooth() +   labs(title = "This is a title",         subtitle = "This is a subtitle",         caption = "This is a caption")  p3 p3 + theme_bc()

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff > The themes > theme_bc()
title: blancocentR
text: release ggplot2 4.0.0, got additional arguments style colors plot. ink foreground colors, paper background colors, accent accent colors. default, set theme_bc() follows: theme_bc(ink = light_gray, paper = "white", accent = col_la, overwrite_ink = TRUE). argument overwrite_ink set TRUE default, means even though ink set light_gray, certain elements inherit color ink, different colors defined theme settings. Let’s take another look plot p3 default theming.  default, ink “black” line geom_smooth() blue (“#3366FF”). apply theme_bc(), points light_text, foreground elements either ull_red (plot title), dark_text (axis titles legend titles), light_text (everything else). accent line now col_la.  default, theme settings theme_bc() overwrites ink almost everywhere. can change using overwrite_ink argument function. Let’s try different look!
code: p3 p3 + theme_bc() p3 + theme_bc(   overwrite_ink = FALSE,    ink = "seashell",    paper = "skyblue4",    accent = "goldenrod"   )

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff > The themes > theme_bc()
title: blancocentR
text: like, can add grid lines. p3, can add x grid lines, y grid lines, . Let’s add x grid lines .
code: p3 + labs(title = "Now with grid lines!") +    theme_bc(grid_x = TRUE) +    theme(legend.position = "none") # remove legend

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff > The themes > theme_bc()
title: blancocentR
text: maps look better without axes. can take advantage ‘void’ argument remove axes one simple step.
code: p1 +    labs(title = "Louisiana",         subtitle = "A map showing all 64 parishes") +   theme_bc(void = TRUE)

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff > The themes > theme_bc()
title: blancocentR
text: replaced old theme_bc() new version, embracing ggplot2 4.0.0. means users must update ggplot2 4.0.0 later use updated theme. However, users don’t wish , legacy version theme still available package, theme_bc_legacy().

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff > The themes
title: blancocentR
text: new addition package theme_lafirst(), adaptation theme_bc() use LA FIRST reporting. Let’s take look p3 LA FIRST theme.

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff > The themes
title: blancocentR
text: Another new addition Blanco Center theme gt tables! ’ll notice looks quite similar BC ggplot theme. carries font families colors text, sizing quite similar well. can customize aspects theme arguments, like base size, font families, text color, options define inside tab_options(). Let’s first look standard gt table, using gtcars dataset comes gt package. caption Now ’ll give refresh theme! caption
code: library(gt)  gt1 <- gtcars %>%    head(10) %>%    select(mfr:hp, trq, ctry_origin) %>%    gt(rowname_col = "mfr") %>%      tab_header(         title = 'Ferrari & Horsepower',         subtitle = md('Data is courtesy of the {gt} *R package*'),      ) %>%      tab_source_note("A source note here") %>%      tab_source_note("Another source note here") %>%      tab_footnote("This is the highest hp (footnote)",                   locations = cells_body(columns = hp, rows = hp == max(hp))     ) %>%      tab_footnote("This is the lowest trq (footnote)",                   locations = cells_body(columns = trq, rows = trq == min(trq))) %>%      tab_caption("A caption here") %>%     tab_stubhead(label = "Make")  %>%     tab_row_group(         label = "Italy",         rows = ctry_origin == "Italy"     ) %>%     tab_row_group(         label = "United States",         rows = ctry_origin == "United States"     ) %>%     tab_spanner(         label = "Body",         columns = c(trim, bdy_style)     ) %>%     tab_spanner(         label = "Specs",         columns = c(hp:trq)     ) %>%    cols_hide(ctry_origin)  gt1 gt1 %>% gt_theme_bc() gt1 %>% gt_theme_bc()

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff > The colors
title: blancocentR
text: Miscellaneous colors still available name. can call specific color collection naming specifically, e.g., misc_pal$jadegreen, print whole list calling misc_pal.  miscellaneous palette also available palette function use directly ggplot discrete variables. See Palette functions palette functions general, Miscellaneous palette use palette.
code: library(scales)  list(   # row 1   "midnight" = "#243e56",    "mint" = "#bcefde",    "berry" = "#8f555a",    "sand" = "#e8d5a6",    "mustard" = "#ae9837",       # row2   "charcoal" = "#3c424e",    "jadegreen" = "#4e7a59",    "pastelgreen" = "#7fc791",    "deepforest" = "#253a2a",    "darkteal" = "#23464f", # urban      # row 3   "cloudfree" = "#62c3dc",    "midblue" = "#5ea2e3",    "silver" = "#94b3b0",    "strawberry" = "#d24a41", # rural   "peachy" = "#f9785e",       # row 4   "blush" = "#eb8d83",    "darkcherry" = "#852f29",    "darkplum" = "#4f2f32",    "darkmaroon" = "#5e3934",    "lilac" = "#a8b9da",       # row 5   "vintageviolet" = "#77839b" # 9th region color )

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff > The colors
title: blancocentR
text: LA FIRST includes two additional colors can used conjunction miscellaneous palette misc_pal: lafirst_pal. Similarly calling colors misc_pal, can access colors name, e.g., lafirst_pal$smokyorchid.

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff > The colors > New LA FIRST colors
title: blancocentR
text: suggest mindful harmful stereotypes visualizing data aggregated e.g., race gender, consider using alternative aesthetic mapping (e.g., x y variables, facets) possible. However, cases makes sense assign colors population groups, LA FIRST suggests use following colors races genders, contained designated color palette vectors.
code: library(tidyr)  race_pal <- list(   "white" = misc_pal$jadegreen,   "black" = col_la,   "hispanic" = misc_pal$strawberry,   "asian" = lafirst_pal$orchid,   "other" = misc_pal$mustard )  race_muted_pal <- list(   "white" = misc_pal$deepforest,   "black" = misc_pal$midnight,   "hispanic" = misc_pal$berry,   "asian" = misc_pal$vintageviolet,   "other" = misc_pal$mustard )  sex_gender_pal <- list(   "men" = lafirst_pal$tealsea,   "women" = misc_pal$peachy )

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff > The colors
title: blancocentR
text: Palette functions generate list colors can used directly ggplot code using, e.g. scale_color_manual() scale_fill_manual(), depending mapped aesthetics.

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff > The colors > Palette functions
title: blancocentR
text: Region palettes map region identifier specific color. Region identifiers can either names numbers. Let’s take look:  Similarly color aesthetics, can map fill:  works mapped color/fill aesthetics variable region_name_DCFS (can see legend title). region color palette assign colors region name opposed region number default. object dcfs_regions, numeric variable region_DCFS character variable region_name_DCFS. region variables parishes louisiana follow pattern. prefer map color region number instead, ’ll need convert region’s numeric value discrete value (e.g., using factor()) specify use region number rather region name inside dcfs_palette() via ‘region’ argument. step, can also darken color region 9 - Monroe using darken argument.  legend title now “factor(region_DCFS)” colors mapped numeric counterpart region names.
code: p4 <- ggplot(louisiana) +    geom_point(     aes(x = estimate, y = region_name_DCFS, color = region_name_DCFS),     size = 3) +   scale_x_continuous(labels = label_number(scale_cut = cut_short_scale())) +   labs(title = "Louisiana population in 2023",         subtitle = "Parish population by DCFS region",         caption = "Source: U.S. Census, 2023 ACS 5-Year estimates, Table B01003",        y = NULL,         x = NULL)  p4 +    scale_color_manual(values = dcfs_palette()) +    theme_bc() +    theme(legend.position = "right") p2 +    scale_fill_manual(values = dcfs_palette()) +    theme_bc(void = TRUE) +    theme(legend.position = "right") ggplot(louisiana) +    geom_point(aes(     x = estimate,     y = region_name_DCFS,     color = factor(region_DCFS) # note the use of factor()     )) +   scale_x_continuous(labels = label_number(scale_cut = cut_short_scale())) +   scale_color_manual(values = dcfs_palette(     region = "number", # use "number" instead of default "name"     darken = 1 # darken by 1     )) +   labs(title = "Louisiana population in 2023",         subtitle = "Parish population by DCFS region",         caption = "Source: U.S. Census, 2023 ACS 5-Year estimates, Table B01003",        y = NULL,         x = NULL) +    theme_bc() +    theme(legend.position = "right")

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff > The colors > Palette functions
title: blancocentR
text: Gradient palettes, just like palettes blancocentR, generate colors. default number colors 7 can adjust number colors using n argument. function generates number colors, can’t use directly continuous variables, discrete variables. However, can make use scale_fill_gradient() defining ‘low’ ‘high’ arguments like :  previous example, use 7th color high didn’t define number colors palette generates. default, number 7, 7th color lightest color. can achieve exact result generating n colors selecting nth value high, e.g. using n = 2:  Note: also adjust base color used generate palette base argument, ’s recommended. hood, function uses monochromeR::generate_palette()4. gradient palettes: la_gradient_palette()  us_gradient_palette()  ur_gradient_palette()  ru_gradient_palette()  slightly different version exists gradient(), function list colors lightens via colorspace::lighten() sequentially 0% 100%. Users can customize number steps function argument n, 11 default achieve colors 10% intervals. example , lighten col_la 20% intervals.
code: ggplot(louisiana) +    geom_sf(aes(fill = estimate)) +    scale_fill_gradient(   low = la_gradient_palette()[1],    high = la_gradient_palette()[7]   ) ggplot(louisiana) +    geom_sf(aes(fill = estimate)) +    scale_fill_gradient(   low = la_gradient_palette()[1],    high = la_gradient_palette(n = 2)[2]   ) show_col(paste(la_gradient_palette())) show_col(paste(us_gradient_palette())) show_col(paste(ur_gradient_palette())) show_col(paste(ru_gradient_palette())) col_la_gradient <- gradients(colors = c("color" = col_la), n = 6) col_la_gradient #> $color100 #> [1] "#4776aa" #>  #> $color80 #> [1] "#6690C4" #>  #> $color60 #> [1] "#84ABE0" #>  #> $color40 #> [1] "#A1C7FD" #>  #> $color20 #> [1] "#D1E3FF" #>  #> $color0 #> [1] "#FFFFFF"  col_la_gradient %>% paste %>% show_col()

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff > The colors > Palette functions
title: blancocentR
text: can access miscellaneous colors two ways: 1) via printing list named colors /individual directly console (see Miscellaneous colors), 2) via function misc_palette(). Just like palette functions blancocentR, function generate colors, 21 exact. can use colors directly ggplot using scale_*_manual(values = misc_palette()), depending mapped aesthetics. work long 1) variable discrete, 2) variable doesn’t exceed 21 distinct levels5.
code: p4 +    scale_color_manual(values = misc_palette()) +    theme_bc() +    theme(legend.position = "none") +   labs(subtitle = "These are colors from the Miscellaneous palette!")

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff
title: blancocentR
text: Wait, function haven’t talked ? show_cvd() helper function allows quickly compare selected colors might look like someone color vision deficiency, print gray-scale. output shows 5 rows: original input colors deuteranope simulation (green cone cells defective) protanope simulation (red cone cells defective) tritanope simulation (blue cone cells defective) desaturated (gray-scale)  Note: hood, function uses scales::show_col()6 functions {colorspace}7 package.

what: A helper package for Blanco Center staff
title: A helper package for Blanco Center staff
text: goal blancocentR facilitate easy mapping Louisiana’s 64 parishes various region designations, well allow cohesive data visualizations across Blanco Center using Blanco Center theme colors.

title: A helper package for Blanco Center staff
text: can install development version blancocentR GitHub :

title: A helper package for Blanco Center staff
text: detailed package documentation, please visit pkgdown site.

title: A helper package for Blanco Center staff
text: basic example can use louisiana data, Blanco Center theme, Blanco Center colors specific DCFS regions:
code: library(blancocentR) library(ggplot2)  data(louisiana) ggplot(louisiana) +    geom_sf(aes(fill = region_name_DCFS)) +    scale_fill_manual(values = dcfs_palette()) +    labs(title = "Louisiana map",        subtitle = "Regions via DCFS") +   theme_bc(void = TRUE) +    theme(legend.position = "right")

what: blancocentR: A helper package for Blanco Center staff — blancocentR-package
title: blancocentR: A helper package for Blanco Center staff — blancocentR-package
text: package Blanco Center staff facilitate cohesive look across data visualizations tbales. package includes ggplot2 themes, theme gt tables, colors color palettes, two data files Louisiana's 64 parishes region designations different agencies organizations (one one without geometry), function join parish polygons region polygons. palettes built using 'monochromeR' package provides methods blending colors. Shapefiles population data U.S. Census acquired via 'tidycensus' package.

title: blancocentR: A helper package for Blanco Center staff — blancocentR-package
text: Maintainer: Claudia Laurenzano claudialaurenzano@gmail.com (ORCID) contributors: Jenna Losh [contributor]

what: A gt theme for Blanco Center tables — gt_theme_bc
title: A gt theme for Blanco Center tables — gt_theme_bc
text: gt_theme_bc() adds Blanco Center theme table created using gt(). Customize table elements like font family, text color sizes.

title: A gt theme for Blanco Center tables — gt_theme_bc
code: gt_theme_bc(   gt,   base_family = "Quicksand",   header_family = "Bitter",   text_color = "#575E66",   title_color = "#a00b0b",   base_size = 12,   ... )

title: A gt theme for Blanco Center tables — gt_theme_bc
text: gt existing gt table object class gt_tbl base_family Font used text. header_family Font used titles: table title, column headers, spanner column headers, row group labels. text_color Color used everything else, except table title. title_color Color used table title. base_size Base text size pts (converted px within function). ... Additional arguments passed gt::tab_options().

what: Louisiana's 64 parishes, FIPS codes, and region designations according to different state agencies and organizations, parish geometry, and parish centers. — louisiana
title: Louisiana's 64 parishes, FIPS codes, and region designations according to different state agencies and organizations, parish geometry, and parish centers. — louisiana
text: Louisiana's 64 parishes, FIPS codes, region designations according different state agencies organizations, parish geometry, parish centers.

title: Louisiana's 64 parishes, FIPS codes, and region designations according to different state agencies and organizations, parish geometry, and parish centers. — louisiana

what: A ggplot2 theme for Blanco Center visualizations — theme_bc
title: A ggplot2 theme for Blanco Center visualizations — theme_bc
text: theme_bc() adds Blanco Center theme plot created using ggplot(). Customize plot elements like font family color axis colors line sizes. Grid lines x y axes can added, axes can removed, e.g. maps. Note: updated version (Fall 2025) requires ggplot2 ver. 4.0.0 longer dependent showtext. prefer use legacy version 2023, please use theme_bc_legacy().

title: A ggplot2 theme for Blanco Center visualizations — theme_bc
code: theme_bc(   base_family = "Quicksand",   header_family = "Bitter",   dark_text = "#1A242F",   light_text = "#575E66",   ink = light_text,   paper = "white",   accent = "#4776aa",   overwrite_ink = TRUE,   void = FALSE,   grid_x = FALSE,   grid_y = FALSE,   base_size = 12,   base_line_size = base_size/22,   base_rect_size = base_size/22 )

title: A ggplot2 theme for Blanco Center visualizations — theme_bc
text: base_family Font used text. header_family Font used titles: plot title, axis titles, legend title. dark_text Color used axis legend titles. light_text Color used everything else, except plot title. ink Color foreground. paper Color background. accent Color accents. overwrite_ink TRUE FALSE: TRUE, theme settings overwrite ink specification. void TRUE FALSE: TRUE, removes axis elements. Suggested maps. grid_x TRUE FALSE: TRUE, adds x grid lines. grid_y TRUE FALSE: TRUE, adds y grid lines. base_size Base text size pts. base_line_size Base line size pts. base_rect_size Base rectangle size pts.

title: A ggplot2 theme for Blanco Center visualizations — theme_bc
text: ggplot2 theme.

title: A ggplot2 theme for Blanco Center visualizations — theme_bc

what: A ggplot2 theme for Blanco Center visualizations — theme_bc_legacy
title: A ggplot2 theme for Blanco Center visualizations — theme_bc_legacy
text: theme_bc_legacy() adds Blanco Center theme plot created using ggplot(). Customize plot elements like font family color axis colors line sizes. Grid lines x y axes can added, axes can removed, e.g. maps. Note: legacy version Blanco Center theme function (developed 2023). updated version, use theme_bc(), developed Fall 2025.

title: A ggplot2 theme for Blanco Center visualizations — theme_bc_legacy
code: theme_bc_legacy(   title_font = "Bitter",   base_font = "Quicksand",   dark_text = "#1A242F",   light_text = "#575E66",   void = FALSE,   grid_x = FALSE,   grid_y = FALSE,   base_size = 12,   base_line_size = base_size/22,   base_rect_size = base_size/22 )

title: A ggplot2 theme for Blanco Center visualizations — theme_bc_legacy
text: title_font Font used titles: plot title, axis titles, legend title. base_font Font used text. dark_text Color used axis legend titles. light_text Color used everything else, except plot title. void TRUE FALSE: removes axis elements. Suggested maps. grid_x TRUE FALSE: adds x gridlines. grid_y TRUE FALSE: adds y gridlines. base_size Base text size pts. base_line_size Base line size pts. base_rect_size Base rectangle size pts.

title: A ggplot2 theme for Blanco Center visualizations — theme_bc_legacy
text: ggplot2 theme.

title: A ggplot2 theme for Blanco Center visualizations — theme_bc_legacy
